column13: Allow an amd64 brlapi.dll to be built using mingw-w64
column20:
The mingw-w64 fork of mingw can produce native amd64 Windows binaries,
however it isn't fully compatible with the 32-bit mingw. This commit fixes
some minor compatibility issues, which leads to it being able to build the
client-side brlapi.dll.
Firstly, the usleep function that is patched in by BRLTTY for certain
versions of mingw is unnecessary when using mingw-w64, as it is already
exposed by its own libc headers. Therefore, this commit prevents the
compilation of this function if the compiler is detected to be mingw-w64.
Secondly, the timespec struct is also already provided when the
mingw-w64 libc is used, so it's similarly excluded.
These two changes are sufficient to get the brlapi.dll itself to compile
(i.e. the api make target). The last change makes sure that the
all-api target (the tests) can also be built. The LANG_MALAGASY is
undefined when using mingw-w64, so it is conditionally removed. Note that
this language constant is not officially supported [1] on Windows, so
removing it when the target is 64-bit Windows should not be harmful.
[1] List of Language Identifier and Constant Strings
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dd318693(v=vs.85).aspx

wherever you are.

The change is fine. Thanks. MKOBJ was for creating incomplete object files, and
MKMOD was for creating shared object files. Of course, they both end up being
the smae sort of operation. MKOBJ would've only ever been used in two places -
the EuroBraille driver and the Vario driver. The latter disappeared a long time
ago when the Baum driver was created. That left the single case of the
EuroBraille driver, which you finally discovered.

column13: atspi2: Fix looking for currently active widget
column20:
The current code was actually not working at all because the initial
sender is SPI2_DBUS_INTERFACE_REG with path SPI2_DBUS_PATH_ROOT, and its
children are applications with SPI2_DBUS_PATH_ROOT too, so when deciding
to recurse, we need to check for both the path and the sender, not only
the path, which may be the same for two sender and make use believe than
we have a loop right from the beginning between SPI2_DBUS_INTERFACE_REG
and applications.
It is however noticeable that some applications do not actually always
expose their widgets as tree, but sometimes as a clique!  We thus need to
take care not only of direct loops, but also loops to further ancestors,
and just stop recursing completely in that case, to avoid an exponential
number of lookups.

I guess the difference with Debian is the ctng_n64part?
The ABI is incompatible with that of the selected emulation error message looks to me like an incoherency between what gcc produces and what ld expects, i.e. rather a bug in the toolchain.
Using gcc -shared instead of ld -r is questionable, because the wording is not really the same in the respective documentations:

gcc -shared: Produce a shared object which can then be linked with other objects to form an executable.
ld -r: Generate relocatable output---i.e., generate an output file that can in turn serve as input to ld.

and the results indeed looks very different e.g. on x86:
$ file gcc-shared-output.o ld-r-output.o
gcc-shared-output.o: ELF 64-bit LSB shared object, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, BuildID[sha1]=c52c1208cfeb208b1b8704588d04ed619355a37e, not stripped
ld-r-output.o: ELF 64-bit LSB relocatable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), not stripped

The first one is already linked with the libc library, has phdr, GOT, etc.

These build failures were (and still are) raised with slightly different toolchains:

http://autobuild.buildroot.org/toolchains/tarballs/mips64el-ctng_n64-linux-gnu.tar.xz

We were also a bit confused about this issue during this patch review, you can see our full discussion here: https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/972614
At that time, I tried to understand why on these toolchains, by default, ld wanted to link a 32 bits binary.  I found that an other possible worakaround would have been to set LD to $(TARGET_LD) -melf64ltsmip
Arnout explained me that

in general, it is possible that additional options have to be passed to ld to
make sure it creates the correct type of ELF file. The buildroot toolchain-wrapper makes
sure that the correct options are passed but as brltty calls ld directly so it bypasses those.

If you think that this PR is not right, I can try to replace it by the "LD" workaround. I think it could be ok as we generally don't like to keep non upstreamable solution.

I came across this issue while trying to write Rust bindings for BrlAPI.
Rust uses a tool called bindgen to automatically generate the low-level
code from a C header file.  It infers mutable fields
for the connection settings struct, which is at least inconvenient
since Rust strings are basically never mutable.
It is very likely that there are workarounds on the Rust side for this,
but its sort of stricter type system makes at least pretending that
something is mutable pretty hard.  I can manually change

We have to tell the OS which minimum size we want. Otherwise we can get

Making the output buffer large enough allows the server to make sure
that it can write its packets to the client without blocking, and get
back to reading data from the client.

We are trying hard to kill that. It has been utterly broken since forever, but unfortunately people hold on to that idea because it kind of worked in the past, even though it is really bad.
If you run startx, then sd_pid_get_session will find it.
However, if you start a modern GNOME desktop (KDE is following, so is everyone else), then it will not work. What GNOME and others do is that they launch a systemd target/service which then starts the desktop and all applications run in the users scope. This launched target and all processes of the running session do not belong to a "session" technically. They "only" belong to the user from the point of view of systemd.
This is what my "session" looks like (systemd-cgls) on a standard F31:
-.slice
├─user.slice
│ └─user-1000.slice
│   ├─user@1000.service
│   │ ├─xdg-permission-store.service
│   │ │ └─2405659 /usr/libexec/xdg-permission-store
│   │  ... all user processes
│   └─session-14.scope
│     ├─2405377 gdm-session-worker [pam/gdm-password]
│     ├─2405396 /usr/bin/gnome-keyring-daemon --daemonize --login
│     ├─2405409 /usr/libexec/gdm-wayland-session /usr/bin/gnome-session
│     ├─2405412 /usr/libexec/gnome-session-binary
│     ├─2406745 /usr/bin/ssh-agent -D -a /run/user/1000/keyring/.ssh
│     └─2944438 gdm-session-worker [pam/gdm-password]

All processes under session-14.scope belong to the session. Everything else is a child of user@1000.service and does not explicitly belong to any session.
With regard to multi-login. The idea is that the desktop environment will expand across multiple logins in the future.

The pulse group exists as the group that the pulse audio server should be
running as, and, as such, exists everywhere but isn't a group that any user

well-defined group within the pulse audio documentation so it's difficult for

likely that the distribution that you're using hasn't defined it.

I also don't know what this issue has to do with building brltty for Chrome OS. I know that Google has been building brltty for that platform for a long time and this isn't an issue for them.

Actually it is. I am working with Google / ChromeOS / ChromiumOS and Gentoo for this. The idea is to block and fix mixed compiler toolchain usage. There are packages in CrOS & Gentoo which build using GCC/binutils tools even though the build should be using only Clang/LLVM. Brltty is one of them.
Here is a CrOS CL which adds some blocking logic which makes building brltty fail. This is only used to detect offenders for now, but we'd like to merge it after fixing the offenders.

Anyway, I think the goal is to not look for a tool if its associated environment variable is already set. If that's correct then please give me a list of all the ones you care about and I'll have a look at coding the change properly.

That is correct. The full list we're currently blocking in CrOS is gcc ld nm as objcopy strip ranlib. In the end we'd like to block all GNU tools for which an LLVM counterpart exists. From what I can see only ld, strip and ranlib are used in brltty.
Thanks again and please ping if you need any more context, if you want me to test something in CrOS, or something else.

column13: Handle Debian's default posix_prefix sysconfig layout
column20:
Fixes Debian's bug: https://bugs.debian.org/1007927
Debian adds a custom sysconfig scheme to system python installs, "posix_local". This is the default scheme, and it redirects local users' Python module installs to /usr/local even though Python is installed with a /usr prefix. Both are on Debian's python's sys.path module search path.
Previously this custom sysconfig scheme was specified in distutils.sysconfig, but not sysconfig itself. As distutils is being deprecated, the custom scheme is now specified in sysconfig, since Debian's Python 3.10 (3.10.2-4).
As far as I can see, pythoncmd is only used in detecting the installed system python, not determining where the built module will be installed, so this patch is sufficient. To control where the module is installed, the approach would be to pass the selected prefix to sysconfig, when querying the install path.
